MyCareer

Tshwane University of Technology

Bachelor's Degree from 2011 to 2014

In the dim recesses of Academia, my dreams collided with the harsh reality that an opinion can affect creative integrity. I found myself in a whirlwind of chaos and excessive amounts of caffeine. Life inadvertently thrust me into a demanding world where teamwork was essential. This was coupled with persistent panic attacks from all the energy drinks. It felt like the universe was conspiring against my sanity, dangling me over an edge for four mentally exhausting years.

While the other students harbored dreams of global directorial acclaim, my ambitions were firmly rooted in pragmatism. My goal was to cultivate skills that could pave a way to financial stability, facilitating my ascent into a higher tax bracket for all the politicians I didn't vote for, but I'm getting ahead of myself. While some may view education merely as a means of survival, I saw it as a versatile tool to fend off hunger by entertaining people with things that look pretty. Now, how do I get them to pay me?

With each passing year, my weary steps mirrored the weight of sleepless nights which culminated in the receipt of a Bachelor's Degree. A piece of paper that seemed absurd amidst the tumultuous journey to obtain it. Yet, within the preposterousness of pursuing it, there lay a strange allure from the audacity it took to attain this document. And so, with a tired smile and a heart heavy with relief, I bid farewell to the treacherous landscapes this piece of paper compelled me to navigate.

South African Broadcasting Corporation

Art Assistant from March, 2016 to May 2016

Graduation was meant to herald my arrival into adulthood, but instead, all I received was a tax number tethered to my name. It turns out the money you sign for doesn't reflect the amount paid into your bank account. Why didn't anyone explain this to me, Mother? Anyway, being broke isn't as exhilarating as it sounds, I know right. It's enough to drive most people to do anything and that's how I stumbled through two doomed feature films before ending up in the heart of Hillbrow, chasing carpentry gigs. Yes, the one in Johannesburg.

The name of the series was "Ithuba" and it never graced television screens because of... reasons. Our art department was a team of three and we scrounged for materials by day before piecing them together by night. We used discarded pallets and fake grass to complete the bare minimum and I'm pretty certain we accrued more debt at the end of the ordeal. As dusk settled, we rested our weary bodies on dilapidated couches in a penthouse nestled within the crime capital of South Africa, daily commutes weren't factored into our budget. Despite the worn appearance of these sofas, they proved surprisingly comfy. After three months of shooting, the director had to pitch the pilot episode to the very producers withholding our salaries.

Reality hit the crew like a ton of bricks when the video editor showed us a cut of the pilot episode, his magnum opus. The final product was more pixelated than the face of a person who asked for anonymity in a documentary. It's as if the editor was trying to hide all the mistakes we made as an art department by compressing the video to the lowest resolution possible. I believe he ran out of disk space, but that's beside the point. Unsurprisingly, this failed to impress. The entire crew abandoned the project with unpaid salaries and left with a bond that can only be forged through a shared dream driven by desperation. But hey, at least it provided me with enough material to incorporate a somewhat respectable logo in my portfolio. Ah, the absurdity of it all.

Clinton Lubbe Productions

Directing Assistant from April, 2016 to December 2017

Let's rewind the clock to my days as a film student, where the thought of a lecture on rifle mics was as enthralling as watching paint dry. But as fate would have it, surprises were in store for me that day. Enter Professor Frank, a maestro of dry wit and subtle humor capable of breathing life into any topic, no matter how mundane. As I sat there, initially feeling as bored as a toddler stripped of their iPad, Professor Frank brandished his very own rifle mic with gusto. He turned a discussion about oscillating magnets into a symphony of "unintentional" innuendos. Giggles bubbled from the back of the classroom like a pair of mice having a brawl in your attic. I reckon his intention was to grab the students' attention, but I digress.

And then, like a relic from the Woodstock era, a figure sauntered into the classroom. He exuded an aura akin to someone who savors every last crumb of avocado toast. His mission? To lure unsuspecting students into an internship for a film dubbed "Somer Son". Little did I know, this day would mark not only my enlightenment on microphone mechanics but also the beginning of my short journey into cinema. With a click, I sent him an email with my trusty Curriculum Vitae attached. A document boasting less substance than a politician's promises. To my astonishment, in July 2014, I was whisked away with a crew for a movie shoot in Mozambique.

Now, back to me toiling away on the SABC project. My phone rang. On the other end? None other than the hippie himself, Clinton Lubbe. He munched away on a piece of avocado toast as we talked. And so began a collaboration that would launch my career into the stratosphere of success. From delving into televisual wizardry to concocting YouTube content that struck gold, every endeavor seemed to flourish. Our music videos, featuring the likes of Jo Black and Robbie Wessels, garnered millions of views, while our rendezvous with Bok van Blerk and Appel on "Lemoene" catapulted us even further into the limelight. And all the while, we ran a photography channel, modest in subscriber count but overflowing with creativity and demanding fans. That was the case until our studio got ransacked.

Welcome to my Portfolio!

Multimedia Programmer

As a Multimedia Programmer, I craft immersive websites, animations, and applications, blending technology and art for engaging user experiences. I enjoy experimenting with new tools and staying updated on multimedia technologies. Seeking collaboration with fellow creatives to transform concepts into long-lasting applications.
